questions.question: According to Newton's First Law, an object moving at constant velocity continues this motion because:
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law: object maintains constant velocity unless acted upon by net external force. Constant velocity means net force = 0.

questions.question: A car cruising at constant highway speed is in:
A skydiver at terminal velocity has:
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, air resistance = weight, so net force = 0.

questions.question: Newton's Second Law states that the acceleration of an object is:
options: Directly proportional to its mass and inversely proportional to the net force.
Directly proportional to the net force and inversely proportional to its mass.
Independent of the mass of the object.
questions.explanation: $a = F_{net}/m$, so acceleration ∝ net force and ∝ 1/mass.

questions.question: In the equation $\vec{F}_{net} = m\vec{a}$, the direction of the acceleration vector is always:
options: Opposite to the direction of the net force.
Perpendicular to the direction of the net force.
The same as the direction of the net force.
In the direction of the largest individual force.
questions.explanation: Since mass is a positive scalar, $\vec{a}$ has the same direction as $\vec{F}_{net}$.

questions.question: If you double the net force acting on an object while keeping its mass constant, the acceleration will:
questions.explanation: $a \propto F_{net}$ when mass constant. Double force → double acceleration.

questions.question: If the same net force is applied to two objects, and Object A has twice the mass of Object B, the acceleration of Object A will be:
options: Four times that of Object B.
questions.explanation: $a \propto 1/m$ when force constant. Twice mass → half acceleration.
